channel.title: California
channel.description: California news and features from the Los Angeles Times.

item.title: Police violence against journalists recalls slaying of Ruben Salazar
item.dc:creator: Daniel Hernandez
item.description: Hundreds of police attacks on journalists were documented during the George Floyd protests. The violence recalls the 1970 slaying of Ruben Salazar.
item.content:encoded: Hundreds of police attacks on journalists were documented during the George Floyd protests. The violence recalls the 1970 slaying of Ruben Salazar.

media:content.media:description: Ruben Salazar during his tenure as news director of the Los Angeles Spanish-language TV station, KMEX.

item.title: In Leimert Park, celebrating Juneteenth is more important than ever, pandemic or not
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Thousands showed up for Juneteenth festival in Leimert Park, a seven-decade tradition
item.content:encoded: Thousands showed up for Juneteenth festival in Leimert Park, a seven-decade tradition

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIFORNIA JUNE 19, 2020-A woman dances to the music during a Juneteenth celebration at Leimert Park Friday. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Bars are open, but masks are required? Shifting coronavirus rules stir confusion
item.dc:creator: Soumya Karlamangla
item.description: Recent announcements about how to deal with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic have left many confused about what is and isn't dangerous.
item.content:encoded: Recent announcements about how to deal with the ongoing COVID-19 pandemic have left many confused about what is and isn't dangerous.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON,CA-JUNE 19 2020--Captivate Nail & Spa in Fullerton is one of the nearly 11,000 nail salons in the state. Wearing gloves, a face shield and mask, Crystal Trang Luong opened the salon only five months before the coronoavirus threat caused her to shut down. After nearly three months closure, June 19, 2020 marks the first day nail salons can reopen under state law. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Post-coronavirus lockdown, customers welcome back a Fullerton nail salon, precautions and all
item.dc:creator: Anh Do
item.description: Nearly three months after coronavirus lockdown, a Fullerton nail salon reopens with new safety guidelines that include taking temperatures and signing a release of liability.
item.content:encoded: Nearly three months after coronavirus lockdown, a Fullerton nail salon reopens with new safety guidelines that include taking temperatures and signing a release of liability.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON,CA-JUNE 19 2020--Captivate Nail & Spa in Fullerton is one of the nearly 11,000 nail salons in the state. Wearing gloves, a face shield and mask, Crystal Trang Luong opened the salon only five months before the coronoavirus threat caused her to shut down. After nearly three months closure, June 19, 2020 marks the first day nail salons can reopen under state law. (Carolyn Cole/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Want to save the world? Do your homework first
item.dc:creator: Nita Lelyveld
item.description: Love-your-neighbor was the drive behind a grass-roots project in a poor L.A. community. It's much harder than it looks.
item.content:encoded: Love-your-neighbor was the drive behind a grass-roots project in a poor L.A. community. It's much harder than it looks.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 16, 2020 - - Jorge Alvarez, with the Pico Union Project, hands out produce to a needy resident at the Pico Union Project in Los Angeles on June 16, 2020. Volunteers with the Pico Union Project hand out produce and other necessities to needy residents and families in the area on Tuesdays and Fridays at 12:30. The Pico Union Project has been handing out food to the community twice a month in recent years -- but began doing so twice a week when the coronavirus hit and needs grew more dire. The Pico Union Project is a seven-year effort to help one of the city's poorest community from a community center located in a historic building that began its life in 1909 as a synagogue and then became a church before musician Craig Taubman bought it in 2013 and began reaching out to the surrounding community. (Genaro Molina / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Amid string of controversial shootings, L.A. County sheriff moves slowly to deploy body cameras
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Dorany Pineda
item.description: After years of discussions, Sheriff's Department still hasn't outfitted deputies with body cameras.
item.content:encoded: After years of discussions, Sheriff's Department still hasn't outfitted deputies with body cameras.

media:content.media:description: GARDENA, CALIF. - JUNE 19, 2020. Jennifer Guardado touches a picture of her brother, Andres Guardado, as she grieves Firiday afernoon, June 19, 2020, at the location in Gardena where the 18-year-old L:atino youth was shot and killed by L.A. County Sheriff's deputies. Family members and community activists said Guardado was working as a security guard in a body shop when the violent encounter with police happened on Thursday, June 18, 2020. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Manhattan Beach fire chief sacked after 'throat' comments
item.dc:creator: Andrew J. Campa
item.description: The analogy of a foot "on their throat," made on multiple instances by Manhattan Beach Fire Chief Daryn Drum, cost him his job Friday evening.
item.content:encoded: The analogy of a foot "on their throat," made on multiple instances by Manhattan Beach Fire Chief Daryn Drum, cost him his job Friday evening.

media:content.media:description: : Manhattan Beach Fire Chief Daryn Drum was fired Friday evening by city manager Bruce Moe after Drum used the analogy "not taking our foot off their throat" at separate events when referencing negotiations with local vendors. This comes less than a month after Minnesota police killed George Floyd by kneeling on his neck.

item.title: To cut LAPD's budget by $150 million, reduce officer ranks below 10,000, report says
item.dc:creator: David Zahniser, Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: Cutting LAPD spending has been a rallying cry for Black Lives Matter-Los Angeles and other grass-roots group and labor unions
item.content:encoded: Cutting LAPD spending has been a rallying cry for Black Lives Matter-Los Angeles and other grass-roots group and labor unions

media:content.media:description: Councilwoman Nury Martinez announces a plan to modify parts of Sepulveda Boulevard known to be havens for sex trafficking.

item.title: With shower curtains, sanitization and social distancing, Los Angeles gyms reopen
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: With unique protocol and creativity, gyms across L.A. County are starting to reopen this week.
item.content:encoded: With unique protocol and creativity, gyms across L.A. County are starting to reopen this week.

media:content.media:description: REDONDO BEACH, CA - JUNE 17: Christian Armenta, left and Jennie Reynoso, right, working out in their "Gainz Pods," during Peet Sapsin's, center, "HIIT" class, which stands for high intensity interval training, at Sapsin's Inspire South Bay Fitness, in Redondo Beach, CA, on Wednesday, June 17, 2020. Sapsin's wife Trinh came up with the pod idea and after researching costs, realized they could build what they needed for safety and distance with PVC piping and shower curtains. The couple built nine of their "Gainz Pods" for the studio, conducting in-person classes and still doing some Zoom classes. (Jay L. Clendenin / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Family says Malcolm Harsch, Black man found hanging from tree, died by apparent suicide
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives
item.description: The man who was found hanged in Victorville killed himself and was not a victim of foul play, his family said.
item.content:encoded: The man who was found hanged in Victorville killed himself and was not a victim of foul play, his family said.

media:content.media:description: A protest was held on Tuesday afternoon in Victorville over the hanging death of Malcolm Harsch, 38, on May 31st. An investigation is underway to determine the cause of death.

Gavin Newsom, carries meals made at the Queen Sheba Ethiopian Cuisine restaurant, to a waiting delivery vehicle in Sacramento, Calif., Friday, June 19, 2020. Newsom, visited the restaurant, owned by Zion Taddese, right, that is participating in the Great Plates Delivered program that provides meals to older adults who are at-risk to COVID-19. (AP Photo/Rich Pedroncelli, Pool)

item.title: Inland Empire counties report highest ever one-day jump in coronavirus cases

item.description: Riverside and San Bernardino counties both reported record-high COVID-19 cases on Thursday. Together, the total case count has reached over 20,000.
item.content:encoded: Riverside and San Bernardino counties both reported record-high COVID-19 cases on Thursday. Together, the total case count has reached over 20,000.

(Gina Ferazzi/Los Angeles Times)

item.content:encoded: As thousands protest racial injustice, many non-Black Americans are considering for the first time the ways in which they contribute to racism.

item.title: Everything you need to know about California's mandatory mask rules
item.dc:creator: Phil Willon, Luke Money, Hannah Fry, Rong-Gong Lin II, Priscella Vega
item.description: Here's everything you need to know about California's mandatory mask rules.
item.content:encoded: Here's everything you need to know about California's mandatory mask rules.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 18: A jogger wears a protective mask to protect from contracting COVID-19 while passing L.A. LIVE Thursday, June 18, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Thursday ordered all Californians to wear face coverings while in public or high-risk settings, including when shopping, taking public transit or seeking medical care, following growing concerns that an increase in coronavirus cases has been caused by residents failing to voluntarily take that precaution. (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)

item.description: Gotovac was one of the oldest working bartenders in Los Angeles. He died from complications of COVID-19.
item.content:encoded: Gotovac was one of the oldest working bartenders in Los Angeles. He died from complications of COVID-19.

media:content.media:description: Coronavirus claims Dan Tana's legendary bartender and resident curmudgeon Mike Gotovac. Miljenko "Mike" Gotovac tended bar at the iconic West Hollywood restaurant for more than 50 years. (Courtesy of Dan Tana's)

item.title: L.A. County coronavirus cases mount, but efforts to slow spread appear to be working, officials say
item.dc:creator: Alex Wigglesworth
item.description: Even as Los Angeles County continues to report high numbers of new coronavirus cases each day, the county remains well-positioned in its fight to slow the virus' spread, making it possible for more sectors of the economy to reopen, health officials maintained Friday.
item.content:encoded: Even as Los Angeles County continues to report high numbers of new coronavirus cases each day, the county remains well-positioned in its fight to slow the virus' spread, making it possible for more sectors of the economy to reopen, health officials maintained Friday.

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA-JUNE 18, 2020-Pedestrians, walk past musicians, Brent Kendell, background left, and Sam Jones, background, right, as they perform at the intersection of Hollywood Blvd. and Highland Ave. in Hollywood. Kendell and Jones call themselves '"The Rock and Blues Brothers." Gov. Gavin Newsom on Thursday ordered all Californians to wear face coverings while in public, following growing concerns that an increase in coronavirus cases has been caused by residents failing to voluntarily take that precaution. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Nail salons, massage parlors and more can reopen in Ventura County following coronavirus closures
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Movie theaters can reopen starting June 26 and wedding ceremonies are allowed to resume, with restrictions.
item.content:encoded: Movie theaters can reopen starting June 26 and wedding ceremonies are allowed to resume, with restrictions.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - MAY 21: Cal Youngblood, 75, is served breakfast by owner Raymundo Sanchez at Busy Bee Cafe on Main Street in downtown Ventura Thursday morning as Ventura County has become the largest county in Southern California to resume dine-in service at restaurants and in-store shopping joining a growing list of California counties that have been given permission to enter phase two of reopening after closures due to coronavirus Covid-19. Clay drove from Simi Valley to eat at Busy Bee Cafe for the first time in months as the restaurant holds special memories because his Mother worked there for many years in the 1960's. "I couldn't wait to come back." He said. Downtown on Thursday, May 21, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

Some businesses in Pasadena and Beverly Hills have boarded up the front of their stores during the coronavirus Covid-19 pandemic possibly to avoid vandalism during the crisis. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Newsom's new mask order won't sit well with the resistance. I know. They're packing my inbox

item.description: How can face coverings be controversial when we know they save lives?
item.content:encoded: How can face coverings be controversial when we know they save lives?

media:content.media:description: HOLLYWOOD, CA-JUNE 18, 2020-Jair Guido, right, wearing a sombrero with an American flag draped over his shoulders, walks with other pedestrians along Hollywood Blvd. in Hollywood. Guido, visiting from Durango, Mexico said that he wore this outfit to show people that he is proud to be a Mexican and that he loves America. Gov. Gavin Newsom on Thursday ordered all Californians to wear face coverings while in public, following growing concerns that an increase in coronavirus cases has been caused by residents failing to voluntarily take that precaution. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times)

Thomas takes place in Lancaster in front of Supervisor Kathryn Barger's office on Thursday, June 18, 2020 in Lancaster, CA. (Irfan Khan / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Newport Beach restaurant Javier's closes after staff member tests positive for COVID-19
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: The upscale eatery wrote on Instagram that it was voluntarily closing the location for deep cleaning and testing, and plans to reopen July 1.
item.content:encoded: The upscale eatery wrote on Instagram that it was voluntarily closing the location for deep cleaning and testing, and plans to reopen July 1.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - JUNE 11: People walk along Harbor boulevard in downtown Fullerton on a warm late Spring day on Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. In an abrupt shift in health orders following weeks of debate over the use of face coverings to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, officials in Orange County announced that OC residents no long have to wear masks in public.

item.title: Adoptions delayed for months by coronavirus closings to get their day in court
item.dc:creator: Seema Mehta
item.description: Foster families whose adoptions were delayed until 2021 because of coronavirus court closings could soon get relief, with in-person hearings no longer required.
item.content:encoded: Foster families whose adoptions were delayed until 2021 because of coronavirus court closings could soon get relief, with in-person hearings no longer required.

media:content.media:description: SOUTHERN CALIFORNIA, CA -- WEDNESDAY, MAY 6, 2020: Natalia and Randall Bergman, shown with their daughter, Jessica Bergman, 16, have been the foster parents of twin girls (who's faces can't be shown, or names printed) since they were three months old. They were set to formally adopt the two-year-olds in April. Then coronavirus hit, and LA County adoption court hearings for non-emergency items have been put on hold. Their adoption hearing is now in 2021. Photo taken in Southern California, CA, on May 6, 2020. (No city where they live can be published.) (Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben/Allen J. Schaben/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Christopher Columbus statue removed from San Francisco's Coit Tower
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: A monument, which has been repeatedly defaced, was removed early Thursday morning and placed in storage, officials said.
item.content:encoded: A monument, which has been repeatedly defaced, was removed early Thursday morning and placed in storage, officials said.

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this May 14, 2014, file photo, a statue of Christopher Columbus stands beneath Coit Tower in San Francisco. The statue in San Francisco was defaced with red paint and graffiti, the day before a federal holiday celebrating the 15th century Italian navigator. Officials say the statue at the foot of Coit Tower in the city's North Beach neighborhood was vandalized sometime Saturday night or Sunday morning. Someone poured red paint over it and drew anarchy symbols and messages on the concrete base that read "Destroy all monuments of genocide" and "Kill all colonizers." City workers cleaned the statue Sunday, Oct. 13, 2019, as thousands celebrated Italian culture. (AP Photo/File)

item.title: Californians must wear face masks in public under coronavirus order issued by Newsom

item.content:encoded: To satisfy a court ruling, Los Angeles city and county agree to shelter 5,300 people in the next 10 months.

Thousands of homeless people living near freeways in L.A. County are in line to receive alternative shelter during the COVID-19 pandemic. (Wally Skalij/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Nine ideas for making our city's public space more race equitable
item.dc:creator: Carolina A. Miranda
item.description: Protests against racism after the killing of George Floyd demonstrate inequities in public space too often designed for white people. How to change that.
item.content:encoded: Protests against racism after the killing of George Floyd demonstrate inequities in public space too often designed for white people. How to change that.

media:content.media:description: A group of diners in an al fresco dining patio in Cincinnati's Over-the-Rhine neighborhood have a beer as marchers walk past, protesting George Floyd's death in Minneapolis in late May 2020. The photo, taken by a photographer for the alt weekly CityBeat, went viral for the different realities it depicted — and was a huge point of discussion among urbanists for how it highlighted the different urban concerns of Black and white communities in the U.S. *** FOR ONE TIME USE ONLY WITH CAROLINA MIRANDA STORY ABOUT URBANISM.***

item.title: Before Juneteenth was widely known, here's how Black Angelenos celebrated emancipation
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: In Los Angeles, the end of slavery was often marked on New Year's Day, before new arrivals from Texas brought the tradition of a Juneteenth party.
item.content:encoded: In Los Angeles, the end of slavery was often marked on New Year's Day, before new arrivals from Texas brought the tradition of a Juneteenth party.

media:content.media:description: Celebration of the abolition of slavery in the District of Columbia, 1866.

item.title: L.A. County allows bars, nail salons, tattoo parlors to reopen Friday
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: The news comes as L.A. County officials announced 1,051 new cases and 36 additional coronavirus-linked deaths, sending the county's death toll past 3,000.
item.content:encoded: The news comes as L.A. County officials announced 1,051 new cases and 36 additional coronavirus-linked deaths, sending the county's death toll past 3,000.

media:content.media:description: PASADENA-CA-MAY 17, 2020: A crowd gathers on the lawn of Catherine and Jonathan Karoly's home in Pasadena, California on Sunday, May 17, 2020 to hear them perform music. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Prosecutors consider charges against woman who went on anti-Asian racist tirades
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Police say Lena Hernandez berated people in two incidents at Charles H. Wilson Park in Torrance and assaulted a person at Del Amo Fashion Center.
item.content:encoded: Police say Lena Hernandez berated people in two incidents at Charles H. Wilson Park in Torrance and assaulted a person at Del Amo Fashion Center.

media:content.media:description: TORRANCE, CA-JUNE 12, 2020: A 42 year old Asian man, (didn't want to give his name), talks to a gathering of people at the conclusion of a rally and workout titled, "We Sweat With You," at Charles H. Wilson Park in Torrance, where a woman made racist, anti-Asian comments to an Asian woman exercising in the park, earlier this week. The same woman made anti-asian comments to this Asian male in the driver's seat of his car parked next to hers. Inside the car at the time was his 11, year old son, left, and 2 year old son, not pictured. At right is Kayceelyn Salmimnao, 32, of Torrance with her daughter, 8 (didn't want to give out her daughter's first name). Kayceelyn said that she was physically attacked by the same woman at Del Amo Fashion Center in October. (Mel Melcon/Los Angeles Times).

item.title: Some DACA recipients rejoiced at Supreme Court ruling. Others are cautiously optimistic
item.dc:creator: Cindy Carcamo, Teresa Watanabe, Anh Do
item.description: The Supreme Court's decision saving DACA reinvigorated many across California, home to more DACA recipients, known as Dreamers, than any other state.
item.content:encoded: The Supreme Court's decision saving DACA reinvigorated many across California, home to more DACA recipients, known as Dreamers, than any other state.

media:content.media:description: Denea Joseph, born in Belize, came to the U.S. when she was 7.

item.title: Federal approval of oil well at Carrizo Plain National Monument sparks outrage
item.dc:creator: Hayley Smith
item.description: The Federal Bureau of Land Management has approved oil drilling in Carrizo Plain National Monument, sparking outrage among conservationists.
item.content:encoded: The Federal Bureau of Land Management has approved oil drilling in Carrizo Plain National Monument, sparking outrage among conservationists.

media:content.media:description: San Luis Obispo County, CA April 9, 2017: Yellow, purple, green and orange colors on the velvet rolling hills the Temblor Range, in Carrizo Plain National Monument in San Luis Obsipo County, CA April 9, 2017. The area has erupted with wildflowers and the crowds are small in this grassy plain west of Bakersfield. Visitors can hick in the hills, or view the gorgeous colors from the road. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Despite protections, landlords seek to evict tenants in Black and Latino areas of South L.A.
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon, Ben Poston
item.description: A Times analysis shows that LA landlords are attempting to evict tenants despite rules barring such actions during the novel coronavirus pandemic.
item.content:encoded: A Times analysis shows that LA landlords are attempting to evict tenants despite rules barring such actions during the novel coronavirus pandemic.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 17: Claudia Mendez, 42, was living in her apartment and quarantining because she had the coronavirus, the landlord locked her out and removed her belonging, on Wednesday, June 17, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Potential illegal evictions during the coronavirus pandemic which have been concentrated, per the data in South LA neighborhoods. (Gary Coronado / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: L.A. school board to consider phasing out school police under intensifying demands
item.dc:creator: Howard Blume
item.description: Officials for the nation's second-largest school system will consider next week a proposal to eliminate the Los Angeles school police department.
item.content:encoded: Officials for the nation's second-largest school system will consider next week a proposal to eliminate the Los Angeles school police department.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 16: David C. Turner III, Manager of Brothers Sons Selves Coalition speaks to students and community members on the steps of LAUSD headquarters where they listed to speakers outside LAUSD Headquarters urging LAUSD to defund school police and eliminate their budget. Los Angeles on Tuesday, June 16, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Anti-vaccine activists, mask opponents target public health officials — at their homes
item.dc:creator: Melody Gutierrez
item.description: County public health officers are increasingly facing threats from anti-vaccine protesters critical of mask requirements amid the coronavirus crisis.
item.content:encoded: County public health officers are increasingly facing threats from anti-vaccine protesters critical of mask requirements amid the coronavirus crisis.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH, CA - APRIL 26: From Left - Chase Gross of Costa Mesa and Savannah Martensen of San Juan Sapistrano along with other demonstrators protest the lockdown and stay-at-home orders they say are crippling the U.S. economy, while essential workers will strike nationwide on May Day to demand safer conditions during the coronavirus outbreak. (Jason Armond / Los Angeles Times)
media:content.media:credit: Jason Armond/Jason Armond/Jason Armond/Los Angeles Times

item.title: Column: All the stupid excuses for not investigating hangings of Black men in the high desert
item.dc:creator: Erika D. Smith
item.description: With the hangings of Black men Malcolm Harsch and Robert Fuller, law enforcement has been inexcusably slow to investigate. 'No evidence' is no excuse.
item.content:encoded: With the hangings of Black men Malcolm Harsch and Robert Fuller, law enforcement has been inexcusably slow to investigate. 'No evidence' is no excuse.

media:content.media:description: PALMDALE, CA - JUNE 15: People gather at a memorial under a tree for Robert Fuller in Poncitlan Square next to Palmdale City Hall where Fuller, a young black man was found hung last week. Nearby protestors are stationed at the doors to Palmdale City Hall which remain closed Monday morning with protestors stationed at each entry door with a sit-in at Palmdale City Hall as organizers demand justice for Robert Fuller, the young black man who was found hung in Poncitlan Square last week. The group is seeking more information on Fuller's case, including the release of the 911 call and the autopsy report. Palmdale City Hall on Monday, June 15, 2020 in Palmdale, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: O.C. officials monitoring increase in ICU hospitalizations from coronavirus
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Despite the uptick in hospitalizations, county leaders indicated Wednesday that there are no plans to tamp down reopenings.
item.content:encoded: Despite the uptick in hospitalizations, county leaders indicated Wednesday that there are no plans to tamp down reopenings.

media:content.media:description: HUNTINGTON BEACH-CA-MARCH 24, 2020: A runner pauses near a taped off staircase leading to the closed Huntington Beach Pier in Huntington Beach on Tuesday, March 24, 2020. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Column: Let civilians police the police. Politicians and law enforcement are protecting bad cops
item.dc:creator: George Skelton
item.description: City councils, boards of supervisors and state legislatures have been afraid to significantly control law enforcement
item.content:encoded: City councils, boards of supervisors and state legislatures have been afraid to significantly control law enforcement

media:content.media:description: On Friday a large group of protestors peacefully demonstrated in front of City Hall in Escondido where they called for police reform and racial justice.
media:content.media:credit: Nelvin C. Cepeda / The San Diego Union-Tribune

item.title: Owner of Irish pub that opened on St. Patrick's Day despite coronavirus order charged with misdemeanor
item.dc:creator: Jake Sheridan
item.description: Joseph Patrick Griffin, owner of Griffin's of Kinsale in South Pasadena, has been charged with a misdemeanor for allegedly violating county health orders on March 17.
item.content:encoded: Joseph Patrick Griffin, owner of Griffin's of Kinsale in South Pasadena, has been charged with a misdemeanor for allegedly violating county health orders on March 17.

media:content.media:description: SOUTH PASADENA-CA-MARCH 19, 2020: Griffin's of Kinsale in South Pasadena is photographed on Thursday, March 19, 2020. The Irish pub was open on Tuesday for St. Patrick's Day despite Los Angeles County giving orders on Monday for all bars, gyms and entertainment centers to shut down. (Christina House / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Days after half brother is found hanging in tree, man is fatally shot amid kidnap probe
item.dc:creator: Matthew Ormseth, Richard Winton, Matt Hamilton, Maya Lau, Alene Tchekmedyian, Leila Miller
item.description: A man fatally shot by deputies in Rosamond was the half brother of Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale.
item.content:encoded: A man fatally shot by deputies in Rosamond was the half brother of Robert Fuller, who was found hanging from a tree in Palmdale.

media:content.media:description: Police cars crowd a Rosamond, Calif., street where deputies fatally shot a man.(KTLA)

item.title: 10 LAPD officers taken off street amid investigations into protest response
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Ten Los Angeles police officers have been taken off the street and assigned to desk duties pending internal investigations into their actions during recent protests, according to the Los Angeles Police Department.
item.content:encoded: Ten Los Angeles police officers have been taken off the street and assigned to desk duties pending internal investigations into their actions during recent protests, according to the Los Angeles Police Department.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: LAPD arrive to arrests protestors for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Ventura City Council votes to require masks inside businesses and government offices
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: The council voted 4 to 3 to require residents wear face coverings inside most businesses and government offices. The city manager will now draft an official ordinance, which the council will vote on at a future date.
item.content:encoded: The council voted 4 to 3 to require residents wear face coverings inside most businesses and government offices. The city manager will now draft an official ordinance, which the council will vote on at a future date.

item.title: One killed after SUV slams into Silver Lake restaurant

item.description: One person was killed and two others were seriously injured when an SUV crashed into the front of a building in Silver Lake.
item.content:encoded: One person was killed and two others were seriously injured when an SUV crashed into the front of a building in Silver Lake.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 17: A crime scene technician documents the scene where one person was killed and at least two others injured when an SUV crashing into a restaurant in Silverlake on Wednesday, June 17, 2020 in Los Angeles, CA. Firefighters responded to a rollover crash in the 1600 block of North Silver Lake Blvd. at around 10:35 a.m. (Dania Maxwell / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Orange and Ventura counties see uptick in coronavirus hospitalizations amid reopening

item.content:encoded: Officials are grappling with whether to allow businesses to resume operations or risk public outcry by tempering reopening efforts.

item.title: Apparent nooses found hanging from trees at Oakland lake spur debate, hate-crime probe
item.dc:creator: Susanne Rust
item.description: Late Wednesday, the Oakland police issued a statement suggesting the apparent nooses could be exercise equipment. Mayor Libby Schaff says the incident will be investigated as a hate crime.
item.content:encoded: Late Wednesday, the Oakland police issued a statement suggesting the apparent nooses could be exercise equipment. Mayor Libby Schaff says the incident will be investigated as a hate crime.

media:content.media:description: Oakland Mayor Libby Schaff has come under increasing scrutiny as her Police Department, already the subject of federal monitoring for 13 years, faces new allegations that officers were having inappropriate sexual relationships with a teenage sex worker.

item.title: Amid outcry over failure to address police reform and racism, Healdsburg mayor to resign
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby
item.description: Residents said Leah Gold made an ignorant statement on the need for police reform in Healdsburg. The mayor says she hopes a person of color takes her spot.
item.content:encoded: Residents said Leah Gold made an ignorant statement on the need for police reform in Healdsburg. The mayor says she hopes a person of color takes her spot.

media:content.media:description: In this June 11, 2020, photo, Mayor Leah Gold gets in to a pointed exchange at the Healdsburg Plaza with protesters during a demonstration in Healdsburg, Calif., against racial inequity and police mistreatment. The mayor resigned Monday, June 15, following comments she made two weeks ago denying the city had a problem with systemic racism. (Kent Porter/The Press Democrat via AP)

item.title: Wind-driven brush fire in Northern California triggers evacuations
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Fed by windy, dry conditions, a brush fire in Calaveras County initially estimated at 10 acres grows to 1,000 acres in the first hour.
item.content:encoded: Fed by windy, dry conditions, a brush fire in Calaveras County initially estimated at 10 acres grows to 1,000 acres in the first hour.

media:content.media:description: Image of the Walker fire taken from AlertWildfire's remote camera near New Hogan Lake on June 16th.

item.title: Far-right 'boogaloo boys' linked to killing of California law officers and other violence
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton, Maura Dolan, Anita Chabria
item.description: Boogaloo members, who include ultra-libertarians and white supremacists, believe in armed insurrection and attacks on the police, experts say.
item.content:encoded: Boogaloo members, who include ultra-libertarians and white supremacists, believe in armed insurrection and attacks on the police, experts say.

media:content.media:description: David L. Anderson, U.S. Attorney for the Northern District of California, speaks during a news conference on Tuesday, June 16, 2020, in Oakland, Calif. An Air Force sergeant already jailed in the ambush killing of a California sheriff's deputy was charged Tuesday in the shooting death of a federal security officer outside the U.S. courthouse in Oakland during a night violent protest last month. Staff Sgt. Steven Carrillo was charged with murder and attempted murder in the killing of federal officer Dave Patrick Underwood, 53. (AP Photo/Ben Margot)

item.title: As L.A. reopens, an underground dance party draws revelers and worries health experts
item.dc:creator: August Brown
item.description: An illicit dance party, held in a South L.A. warehouse on Friday night, may have been the city's first live music event since the coronavirus shutdown.
item.content:encoded: An illicit dance party, held in a South L.A. warehouse on Friday night, may have been the city's first live music event since the coronavirus shutdown.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 12, 2020: Party-goers wearing masks enter through a secret red iron gate to attend an underground rave show during the coronavirus pandemic on June 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. Even as COVID-19 cases spike in CA, and the state continues to prohibit concerts and large gatherings, some in L.A.'s underground rave scene have decided it's over, and they're beginning to throw after-hours shows again.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 'Is my son next?' Hanging death of Black man sparks outrage and suspicion in Victorville
item.dc:creator: Ruben Vives, Andrew J. Campa
item.description: A peaceful demonstration Tuesday in Victorville called for police accountability and an independent investigation into the hanging death of a Black man.
item.content:encoded: A peaceful demonstration Tuesday in Victorville called for police accountability and an independent investigation into the hanging death of a Black man.

media:content.media:description: A protest was held on Tuesday afternoon in Victorville over the hanging death of Malcolm Harsch, 38, on May 31st. An investigation is underway to determine the cause of death.

item.title: Netflix CEO Reed Hastings donates $120 million to support historically Black colleges and universities
item.dc:creator: Kristi Sturgill
item.description: The donation to the United Negro College Fund, Spelman College and Morehouse College is the largest ever individual gift to HBCU scholarships
item.content:encoded: The donation to the United Negro College Fund, Spelman College and Morehouse College is the largest ever individual gift to HBCU scholarships

media:content.media:description: FILE - In this Aug. 2, 2011, file photo, Netflix CEO Reed Hastings speaks at a meeting in Palo Alto, Calif. Netflix Chairman and CEO Hastings is getting a 50 percent pay bump in 2014 after a year in which shares of the online video subscription company quadrupled to an all-time high. (AP Photo/Paul Sakuma, File) ** Usable by LA and DC Only **

item.title: In the Antelope Valley, a history of racism fuels suspicions over Robert Fuller's death
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai, Hailey Branson-Potts
item.description: In the Antelope Valley, where there is a long history of racial tension, Black residents are skeptical of authorities' claims that the death of Robert Fuller by hanging was a suicide.
item.content:encoded: In the Antelope Valley, where there is a long history of racial tension, Black residents are skeptical of authorities' claims that the death of Robert Fuller by hanging was a suicide.

media:content.media:description: Deonte Kemp, 27, of Los Angeles lights candles under a tree where mourners gather at two memorials for Robert Fuller in Poncitlan Square next to Palmdale City Hall.

item.content:encoded: COVID-19 hospitalizations are beginning to tick up in places such as Ventura and Orange counties, leading officials in some areas to slow reopening.

item.title: LAUSD says recycler is endangering Jordan High students with 'sharp metal projectiles'
item.dc:creator: Tony Barboza, Howard Blume
item.description: L.A. school officials are suing S&W Atlas Iron & Metal Co., saying it has released metal projectiles, toxic fumes and metallic dust onto Jordan High School in Watts.

item.title: Column: Why are so many people not wearing masks? Here's how they explain it
item.dc:creator: Steve Lopez
item.description: Put down your pitchforks, people. Masks won't hurt you and they could save your life — or someone else's.
item.content:encoded: Put down your pitchforks, people. Masks won't hurt you and they could save your life — or someone else's.

media:content.media:description: A crowd congregates in the Gaslamp Quarter Friday evening.

item.title: Column One: In Orange County, seniors risk COVID-19 to protest death of George Floyd
item.dc:creator: Gustavo Arellano
item.description: The average age in Laguna Woods is 78, making residents prime targets for the coronavirus. But that didn't keep dozens from turning out to say Black lives matter.
item.content:encoded: The average age in Laguna Woods is 78, making residents prime targets for the coronavirus. But that didn't keep dozens from turning out to say Black lives matter.

media:content.media:description: LAGUNA WOODS, CALIF. - JUNE 12, 2020. Cyndee Whitney, 73, joins a protest in support of Black Lives Matter along El Toro Road in Laguna Woods on Friday, June 12, 2020. Laguna Woods is a community made up largely of senior citizens in Orange County. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Woman driving near protests says LAPD foam round injured her, files $10-million claim
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: The woman's attorney said an officer in a squad car fired the round, calling it willful misconduct.
item.content:encoded: The woman's attorney said an officer in a squad car fired the round, calling it willful misconduct.

media:content.media:description: A LAPD foam bullet left Jasmine Morales, 26, with a broken cheekbone and brain injury.

item.title: Unarmed specialists, not LAPD, would handle mental health, substance abuse calls under proposal
item.dc:creator: Dakota Smith
item.description: Several L.A. City Council members called for a new emergency-response model that uses trained specialists, rather than LAPD officers, to respond to calls for service not related to violence.
item.content:encoded: Several L.A. City Council members called for a new emergency-response model that uses trained specialists, rather than LAPD officers, to respond to calls for service not related to violence.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles police officers talk to a homeless man on San Pedro Street along downtown L.A.'s skid row.

item.title: Coronavirus hospitalizations creep up in Ventura County, raising concerns about reopening
item.dc:creator: Luke Money, Rong-Gong Lin II, Iris Lee, Colleen Shalby
item.description: "At this point, it would be foolhardy to just open up and continue to open up," the county's public health officer said Tuesday.
item.content:encoded: "At this point, it would be foolhardy to just open up and continue to open up," the county's public health officer said Tuesday.

media:content.media:description: VENTURA, CA - APRIL 22: Local historian Cynthia Thompson crosses South California Street on East Main in downtown Ventura Wednesday morning as Ventura County on Saturday modified its stay-at-home order to permit some businesses to reopen and some gatherings to take place for the first time since the restrictions were issued to fight the spread of the coronavirus COVID-19. Cynthia said "I think this is absolutely necessary. It's exactly like the plague of 1918. Mandatory masks, closing everything down, and they used churches as hospitals." "You have to give people hope, but you have to be very cautious. It's an invisible enemy." She added. Ventura on Wednesday, April 22, 2020 in Ventura, CA. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: An 'empty homes' tax could go before L.A. voters in November
item.dc:creator: Emily Alpert Reyes
item.description: The L.A. City Council is considering whether to put a measure on the November ballot asking voters to approve a new tax on empty homes. The proposal is seen as a way to nudge landlords into putting more units back on the market.
item.content:encoded: The L.A. City Council is considering whether to put a measure on the November ballot asking voters to approve a new tax on empty homes. The proposal is seen as a way to nudge landlords into putting more units back on the market.

media:content.media:description: Councilman David Ryu in 2015
media:content.media:credit: Lawrence K. Ho / Los Angeles Times

item.title: California spent $38.2 million on CHP officers at George Floyd protests
item.dc:creator: Patrick McGreevy
item.description: The CHP incurred $38.2 million in overtime costs policing the recent fiery protests triggered by the death of George Floyd, according to a report.
item.content:encoded: The CHP incurred $38.2 million in overtime costs policing the recent fiery protests triggered by the death of George Floyd, according to a report.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - MAY 28, 2020: A protester tosses a bottled water on a CHP vehicle as other Black Lives Matter protesters swarm the car in a rally in front of LAPD headquarters to protest the death of George Floyd during the coronavirus pandemic on May 28, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. (Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Activists, students, parents rally for end to L.A. school police
item.dc:creator: Sonali Kohli, Howard Blume
item.description: Students and community members are calling for the dismantlement of the L.A. school police. Supt. Austin Beutner says he supports eliminating the use of pepper spray and chokeholds.
item.content:encoded: Students and community members are calling for the dismantlement of the L.A. school police. Supt. Austin Beutner says he supports eliminating the use of pepper spray and chokeholds.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES CA. JUNE 16, 2020 - Hundreds of students and community members gathered at the Miguel Contreras Learning Complex, just east of downtown, Tuesday June 16, 2020, calling to eliminate the $70 million Los Angeles School Police Department, a force of about 470 officers and civilians. (Al Seib / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Mysterious explosion, fire shuts down Highway 1 in beach town north of San Francisco
item.dc:creator: Associated Press
item.description: Stinson beach was rocked by an explosion that prompted authorities to close Highway 1 after a fire spread to multiple buildings Tuesday in the beach community north of San Francisco.
item.content:encoded: Stinson beach was rocked by an explosion that prompted authorities to close Highway 1 after a fire spread to multiple buildings Tuesday in the beach community north of San Francisco.

media:content.media:description: Strict water rationing will be imposed on the tiny Marin County town of Stinson Beach, where the population can swell to as many as 15,000 on summer weekends.

item.title: 'They were bent on silencing us': Groups clash in Orange County over mask requirements
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Protesters shouted, "Hey hey, ho ho, these masks have got to go," and mocked speakers for sanitizing their hands.
item.content:encoded: Protesters shouted, "Hey hey, ho ho, these masks have got to go," and mocked speakers for sanitizing their hands.

media:content.media:description: FULLERTON, CA - JUNE 11: A man jogs on the sidewalk, past people waiting along Harbor boulevard in downtown Fullerton on a warm late Spring day, Thursday, June 11, 2020 in Fullerton, CA. In an abrupt shift in health orders following weeks of debate over the use of face coverings to stem the spread of the novel coronavirus, officials in Orange County announced that OC residents no long have to wear masks in public. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: 60 Freeway lanes will be closed four nights this week for 'Swarm' project
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Lanes of 60 Freeway will be closed, in alternating directions, in the Chino area over the next four nights so crews can work on the Pipeline Avenue bridge.
item.content:encoded: Lanes of 60 Freeway will be closed, in alternating directions, in the Chino area over the next four nights so crews can work on the Pipeline Avenue bridge.

media:content.media:description: A new air monitoring site near the 60 Freeway in Ontario, a route frequently used by trucks, showed the highest concentrations of lung-damaging soot in the region.

item.title: Statue of colonizer John Sutter removed after being defaced in Sacramento
item.dc:creator: Kailyn Brown
item.description: Last week, as monuments were being removed across the globe — sometimes forcibly — the statue of John Sutter was vandalized with red paint.
item.content:encoded: Last week, as monuments were being removed across the globe — sometimes forcibly — the statue of John Sutter was vandalized with red paint.

media:content.media:description: Workers remove a statue of John Sutter, a Swiss settler who built the first European settlement on the site of the city of Sacramento, outside Sutter hospital in midtown on Monday, June 15, 2020. Some historical accounts describe Sutter as using Native Americans as slaves and raping Native American girls as young as age 12. (Daniel Kim/The Sacramento Bee via AP)

item.title: DEA investigating drug thefts and damage at 177 pharmacies in L.A. area
item.dc:creator: Kevin Rector
item.description: Burglaries of pharmacies amid the protests disrupted patients' access to medication and spurred fears the stolen drugs would be resold on L.A. streets.
item.content:encoded: Burglaries of pharmacies amid the protests disrupted patients' access to medication and spurred fears the stolen drugs would be resold on L.A. streets.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CALIF. - MAY 30, 2020. Looters ransack a Walgreens store alog Broadway in downtown Los Angeles on Saturday, May 30, 2020. About 200 people marched through downtown streets, slowing traffic and keeping ahead of police trying to cut them off. Looting and the destruction of public and private property has spread across the country in the wake of the the police killing of George Floyd, a black man in Minneapolis. (Luis Sinco/Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Suspect in killing of 2 Bay Area officers tied to right-wing 'boogaloo' group, prosecutors allege
item.dc:creator: Maura Dolan, Richard Winton, Anita Chabria
item.description: Air Force Sgt. Steven Carrillo, charged with the killing of a sheriff's sergeant, now faces federal charges in the Oakland slaying of a federal officer.
item.content:encoded: Air Force Sgt. Steven Carrillo, charged with the killing of a sheriff's sergeant, now faces federal charges in the Oakland slaying of a federal officer.

media:content.media:description: Santa Cruz County Sheriff's Department mug shot of suspect Steven Carrillo who was arrested Saturday, June 6, on suspicion of fatally shooting a sheriff's deputy in the Santa Cruz Mountains town of Ben Lomond.

item.title: 'Gimme Shelter' podcast: How the California Constitution affects housing for poor people
item.dc:creator: Liam Dillon
item.description: Passed in 1950, Article 34 of the California Constitution requires a public vote before the building of public housing.
item.content:encoded: Passed in 1950, Article 34 of the California Constitution requires a public vote before the building of public housing.

media:content.media:description: Residents of Chavez Ravine, on the site of what is now Dodger Stadium, await the next move in an eviction battle in 1959. They had been given a deadline to move out of their homes.

item.title: Renegade restaurants and maskless partying at bars set off new coronavirus alarm
item.dc:creator: Colleen Shalby, Alex Wigglesworth, Paul Sisson, Matt Szabo
item.description: California health officials fear outbreaks if people don't follow public health rules as the state reopens. Evidence shows rules aren't being followed.
item.content:encoded: California health officials fear outbreaks if people don't follow public health rules as the state reopens. Evidence shows rules aren't being followed.

media:content.media:description: People enjoy a night out in the Gaslamp Quarter in San Diego on Saturday, June 13, 2020.

item.title: All Black Lives Matter street painting will remain in Hollywood for now
item.dc:creator: Luke Money
item.description: Officials and community members are considering a more permanent marker to denounce racial injustice and support LGBTQ rights.
item.content:encoded: Officials and community members are considering a more permanent marker to denounce racial injustice and support LGBTQ rights.

media:content.media:description: Hollywood, CA, Monday, June 15 2020 - Crews begin to erase the All Black Lives Matter sign painted on Hollywood Blvd., across from the Hollywood and Highland complex. (Robert Gauthier / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: Death toll from coronavirus at Chino prison rises to 15 after two more inmates die
item.dc:creator: Hannah Fry
item.description: Fifteen prisoners have died of complications related to the coronavirus at the California Institution for Men in Chino.
item.content:encoded: Fifteen prisoners have died of complications related to the coronavirus at the California Institution for Men in Chino.

media:content.media:description: Schaben, Allen J.   CHINO: AUG. 10, 2009: As viewed through the afternoon heat waves, a corrections officer looks out from a tower over barbed wire fences and transport busses at the California Institution For Men State Prison in Chino. California prisons remain on lockdown after Saturday's riot in Chino. On Aug. 8 a violent riot broke out at the California Institution of Men in the West reception facility. About 200 inmates were injured and 30 remain hospitalized with nonlife threatening injuries. Some say the riot is a result of racerelated tensions between Blacks and Latinos.(Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times
media:content.media:credit: Allen J. Schaben / Los Angeles Times

item.title: The hanging deaths of two Black men were initially dismissed. Now they are getting intense investigations
item.dc:creator: Alene Tchekmedyian, Luke Money, Kevin Baxter, Richard Winton
item.description: An FBI spokeswoman says the agency will monitor both probes into the hanging deaths of Robert Fuller in Palmdale and Malcolm Harsch in Victorville.
item.content:encoded: An FBI spokeswoman says the agency will monitor both probes into the hanging deaths of Robert Fuller in Palmdale and Malcolm Harsch in Victorville.

media:content.media:description: Protesters stage a sit-in at Palmdale City Hall as organizers demand justice for Robert Fuller.

item.title: As L.A. reopens, an underground dance party draws revelers and worries health experts
item.dc:creator: August Brown
item.description: An illicit dance party, held in a South L.A. warehouse on Friday night, may have been the city's first live music event since the coronavirus shutdown.
item.content:encoded: An illicit dance party, held in a South L.A. warehouse on Friday night, may have been the city's first live music event since the coronavirus shutdown.

media:content.media:description: LOS ANGELES, CA - JUNE 12, 2020: Party-goers wearing masks enter through a secret red iron gate to attend an underground rave show during the coronavirus pandemic on June 12, 2020 in Los Angeles, California. Even as COVID-19 cases spike in CA, and the state continues to prohibit concerts and large gatherings, some in L.A.'s underground rave scene have decided it's over, and they're beginning to throw after-hours shows again.(Gina Ferazzi / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: This kind of mask can actually spread the coronavirus. Here's how to fix it
item.dc:creator: Rong-Gong Lin II
item.description: Exhalation vents in masks can reduce moisture buildup but also potentially spread infectious droplets. But the fix is easy. Grab some tape.
item.content:encoded: Exhalation vents in masks can reduce moisture buildup but also potentially spread infectious droplets. But the fix is easy. Grab some tape.

media:content.media:description: An N95 mask that has a valve can let germs escape.

item.title: Las Vegas is waking up. This California town on the road there is struggling to come back to life
item.dc:creator: Stephanie Lai
item.description: Closure of Las Vegas' casinos brought tiny Baker, Calif., to a virtual standstill
item.content:encoded: Closure of Las Vegas' casinos brought tiny Baker, Calif., to a virtual standstill

media:content.media:description: BAKER, CA - JUNE 09: Alien Fresh Jerky is a popular haunt for people passing through Baker, as seen on Tuesday, June 9, 2020 in Baker, CA. The tiny town - with a population of roughly 600 - sits along Interstate 15, is a popular rest stop for those traveling to Las Vegas. (Kent Nishimura / Los Angeles Times)

item.title: LAPD spent $40 million during protests, coronavirus; officer overtime pay is curtailed
item.dc:creator: Richard Winton
item.description: LAPD spent more than $40 million in policing George Floyd protests as well as dealing with fallout from the coronavirus, running out of overtime money.
item.content:encoded: LAPD spent more than $40 million in policing George Floyd protests as well as dealing with fallout from the coronavirus, running out of overtime money.

media:content.media:description: Los Angeles, CA JUNE 2, 2020: LAPD arrive to arrests protestors for curfew vilotation after a day of peaceful protest against police brutality and to demonstrate in Los Angeles, CA. The protests were sparked by the death of George Floyd. (Francine Orr/ Los Angeles Times)
